awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Quantum Simulation With Strings of Trapped Ions
awd_abstract_narration:
Most scientists believe that all known phenomena in the macroscopic everyday world follow from a few fundamental quantum physics principles. In practice, however, the connection between the macroscopic world and the quantum world is poorly understood. A particular puzzle is how dissipative effects such as friction emerge from quantum physics. In this study, crystals of trapped ions will be used to study the emergence of static friction from the fundamental principles of quantum mechanics. For this an ion crystal will be cooled close to the absolute zero point of temperature and placed in a periodic potential formed by two interfering light beams. In this way the hypothesis that the onset of friction is connected to a quantum phase transition will be tested.

These research efforts will be complemented by modernizing physics education with a quantum information inspired syllabus. The material will emphasize a conceptual understanding of quantum phenomena using modern experiments and be complemented by a lab-course on entangled photons and quantum cryptography. Broader impacts include the integration of undergraduate students into research activities. The Summer High-School Apprenticeship Research Program of the Berkeley Nanoscience and Nanoengineering Institute will be used to reach out to high-school students and, in particular, to encourage members of underrepresented groups to study sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum simulation with strings of trapped ions


Most scientists believe that all known phenomena in the macroscopic everyday world follow from a few fundamental quantum physics principles.However, understanding the emergence of such properties is verydifficult. For instance, even characterizing a general moderately sizedquantum mechanical system is beyond our current experimental andtheoretical capabilities. We set up an apparatus to investigate howmacroscopic properties such as damping and friction emerge when ioncrystals are cooled to ultra-low temperatures and quantum mechanicaleffects become relevant.


To help illuminating the role of quantum mechanics in macroscopicsystems, we introduced a novel method to detect quantum propertiesExperimentally. Our method allows one to track individual quantumexcitations even at high temperatures.We test our method on ion strings ranging from one to 42 Calcium ions andfind a favorable scaling behavior with the number of particles. This supportsthe claim that our method can be used to study quantum mechanical phenomenaon the macroscopic scale. We finally showedtheoretically that it can also be used to identify distinct phases of matter,highlighting the universality of our method.


In addition to the original intent of the experimental setup, we also used the same apparatus to implement novel measurement methods for atomic properties as well as to realize a Michelson-Morley test for electrons to test for the isotropy of space for electrons. We found no deviations from isotropy of space at the level of 1E-18, making this a more precise test of Lorentz symmetry than the current best conventional Michelson-Morley experiments using light.


The project also supported efforts to modernize physics education with a quantum information inspired syllabus. The developed course emphasized a conceptual understanding of quantum phenomena by illustrating the abstract concepts of quantum mechanics with modern experiments using single photons and atoms. In addition, we developed a hands-on quantum mechanics experience for students. In this laboratory course, students set up a source for entangled photons and prove rigorously that our intuition we gain from everyday experience is not compatible with the laws of nature. In particular, the students show that either the properties of systems are undefined or that distant systems influence each other instantaneously.


Apart from these broader impacts for physics education, we also integrated 10 undergraduate students into modern research and reached out twice to high-school students via the "The Summer High-School Apprenticeship Research Program of the Berkeley Nanoscience and Nanoengineering Institute".
